The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.p: THE PLANETS.
Mercury is invisible at the beginning of the month and an evening star at the end.
Venus is a morning star throughout the month.
Mars is visible from 2.30 a.m. at the beginning of the month and from a little after midnight at the end.
Jupiter rises at a little after 2 a.m. at the beginning of the month and at midnight towards the end.
Saturn may be seen after 10 p.m. at the beginning of the month and 2 hours earlier at the end.
The chief constellations in the South at 9 p.m. are Hercules, near the zenith, Ophiucus about 60 deg. and Scorio (chief star Antares) about 30 deg. above the horizon.

MONDAY, JULY 3, 1905.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
div.p: The opinion seems to be gaining ground in most of the capitals of Europe that Germany has not only reaped no advantage from her gratuitously unfriendly attitude towards France in relation to Morocco, but has created a situation of no small embarrassment for herself. By her action she has once more drawn attention to the real motives which underlie her policy, and the tortuous methods by which she endeavours to promote it. The German Press campaign, by which it was sought to discredit England's good faith in the eyes of France, was undoubtedly inspired in the traditional German style. But France has not been permanently misled, and the clumsy attempts of Prince Bülow to cast doubts upon British bona fides, and to destroy the entente now happily established between the two countries, has recoiled upon its author. French opinion is beginning to be strongly expressed in regard to the stream of unsolicited advice from German newspapers and politicians as to what France should, or should not, do in the management of her own affairs, and a very important manifestation of French opinion has appeared in the “Echo de Paris.’’ It is from the pen of M. Delafosse, one of the ablest, most respected, and level-headed members of the Chamber of Deputies. Though a member of the Conservative “Right,” and its foremost spokesman on questions of foreign policy, he has invariably risen in the discussion of these matters above mere party considerations, and is, therefore, justly regarded as speaking for France totally irrespective of its political groups. The opinions of such a man are worthy of careful consideration, and the “Echo de Paris” has done a public service in making its columns the channel for M. Delafosse’s remarks on the situation.

The efforts of Germany have been directed to convince France that for her permanent welfare she has no alternative but a Franco- German Alliance. M. Delafosse maintains, on the contrary, that she has another alternative policy, that of a defensive alliance with Great Britain. He reminds his countrymen that the real reason which has led Germany to intervene in Morocco, in regard to which a year ago she declared she had no special interest, has been the rapprochement between England and France, and the obvious loosening in the bonds of the Triple Alliance. The Kaiser cannot endure the thought that France and England are at one, and he desires, at almost any cost, to ensure that France shall join his soldiers and sailors in the event of that conflict between England and Germany which not a small or unimportant section of the German nation desires ultimately to take place. M. Delafosse hints his belief that M. Delcassé had already drafted a defensive treaty between France and England, and he is of opinion that if such an alliance were offered to France it should be accepted, as it would be of the greatest value to her in peace or war. He is well aware that the policy of England is one of non-aggression. We only desire to preserve and develop our already enormous Empire, and the French know that we are not likely to go to war, except in the last resort, when our honor, our rights, and our interests cannot be preserved by any other means. Such a policy exactly harmonises with that which France herself has, with hardly an exception, pursued for the last five and thirty years. No nation in Europe is now more genuinely pacific in its tendencies and aims than France: the disturbing element is the great military Power on the right bank of the Rhine, and the ambitions of its ever-restless Monarch. These are rapidly becoming a standing menace to the peace of the world, and for Russia, in particular, they are inducing some very disagreeable reflections as to the real value of the friendship and advice of Germany.

div.head: THE ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: Every Tuesday and Friday evening large crowds assemble in the Esbekieh Gardens to listen to the military band performances. It is difficult to calculate the number who attend, but probably 4,000 is a fair estimate, and it is therefore astonishing that not one policeman is ever to be found on duty in the gardens on these occasions. The natural consequence of the absence of police is a complete want of order, and a gradual diminution of the attendance of the better classes. Fights over the possession of chairs are frequent, and it is a common sight to see some ill-mannered individual appropriating three or four chairs on the chance of his friends turning up. Chairs, too, are placed anywhere and everywhere, according as to where the individual may desire to seat himself, with the consequence that those who wish to promenade find their way blocked at every turn. We should have thought it hardly necessary for the Press to have to point out to the police authorities that wherever a crowd of some thousands congregates there should be a number of policemen to maintain order. Having done so we trust that a sufficient number of police will in future be sent to the gardens on these nights to keep order, and that steps will immediately be taken to remove all cause for farther complaint.

div.head: RUSSIAN MUTINY. CONTRADICTORY NEWS. REPORTED MUTINY OF FLEET. ODESSA A MILITARY CAMP.

div.p: The mutiny here has been put down. (R.)

There was no fighting here yesterday, the rioters being cowed by the troops which are encamped throughout the city. The population thronged the house-tops all the afternoon, witnessing the manœuvring of the squadron, which culminated in the unconditional surrender of the “Potemkin,” whose demand for amnesty was refused. The “Potemkin” hauled down the red Hag when she was surrounded by the battleships, which prepared to concentrate their fire upon her. (Reuter.)
The “Potemkin” has surrendered. The crew have been transferred to ships of the squadron which came from Sevastopol. (Havas.)

The correspondent of the “Daily Mail" telegraphs from Odessa that, despite the announcement of the authorities that the “Potemkin has surrendered, he is informed on trustworthy authority that she has been joined by the battleship “Georgi Pobyedonosets,” and that both are now using searchlights, as if expecting the attack of the rest of the squadron, which is fifteen miles distant. (Reuter.)
No news has been received from Odessa, except a private telegram stating that the “Potemkin" has been joined by another mutinous battleship. (Reuter.)
The squadron with which Admiral Kruger left did not include the “Georgi Pobyedonosets.” The Admiral has returned here with his four battleships, but without the cruiser “Kazarsky.”
It is stated here that she will return in the evening with the “Potemkin.” (Reuter.)

The latest news from Odessa which has been allowed to reach here says that the “Potemkin” and the “Georgi Pobyedonosets” are still there, and that the authorities refused permission for the men of the “Potemkin” to land and buy food. They have been told to send lists of requirements. (Reuter.)
The American Consul at Odessa, Mr. Heenan, now cables a reported mutiny in the fleet. The “Potemkin” and another battleship are still there. (Reuter.)
The Russian ship “Potemkin” and the torpedo boat 267 anchored in the harbour this evening. (Havas.)

Strong forces of troops are posted so as to bar ail access to the harbour, to prevent the public from approaching any point overlooking the sea ; it is therefore impossible to see the movements of the warships. This explains the contradictory reports, and it is still uncertain whether the “Potemkin” has surrendered or been joined by the ‘ Pobyedonosets.” The city is a prey to the wildest rumours.
(Later). It is now clear that the “Potemkin” did not surrender.

The “Kniaz Potemkin,” with the mutineers on board, has sailed apparently in the direction of the Roumenian coast. It is admitted that the crew of the “Pobyedonosets,” which is the only warship at present off the port, has mutinied, but it is officially announced that the mutineers intend to surrender. The British Consul General has arranged for five steamers, of which four are British, to wait off the port, to remove the British and other foreigners, if there is any danger.
The greatest excitement prevails in the town and crowds are endeavouring to leave. (R )

div.head: DEATH OF MR HAY.
div.p: Mr. Hay, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, is dead. (Reuter )

it was only a week ago that the annonnce-ment was made that Mr. Hay was suffering from a return of the malady from which it was thought be had just made a complete recovery. He had made all arrangements for resuming the active discharge of his duties as Secretary of State. Mr. Hay had been Secretary of State for seven years, and was in his sixty-eighth year. It is stated that be had decided not to return to Washington after his recent illness, but yielded to President Roosevelt's solicita tion from a sense of duty.

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Somerset v. Worcestershire and Notts v. Leicestershire have been abandoned on account of the rain. The rest of the matches for this date have been drawn, (Reuter

div.head: THE PEACE CONFERENCE.
DELEGATES TO HAVE FULL POWERS.
div.p: it is officially announced that the Russian and Japanese Governments have notified President Roosevelt that they have appointed plenipotentiaries to meet as soon as possible after the first of August. Both sides have entrusted full powers to their representatives to negotiate and conclude a treaty, subject to the ratification of the respective Governments. (Reuter.)
General Sakharoff, Minister of War, has resigned. (Reuter.)
General Sakharoff, Minister of War, has resigned in consequence of a disagreement with the Committee of Defence.
The mobilisation has caused disturbances. (Havas.)

div.head: NEW JAPANESE FOREIGN LOAN.
div.p: Mr. Takahashi, the Japanese Financial Agent, has arrived in England for the purpose of arranging, at an early date, the issue of a foreign loan of £30,000,000 at London and New York, on the security of the tobacco monopoly (Reuter.)

div.head: THE “TEREK” DISARMED.
div.p: The Russian cruiser “Terek” has been disarmed here. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
AGREEMENT CONSIDERED DEFINITE.
div.p: M. Rouvier has handed Prince Radolin the note laying down the conditions of the acceptance of the conference. The newspapers consider the agreement as definite. (Havas.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil Pasha arrived at Cairo to-day from England.
Mr. Boyle, First Secretary to the British Agency, will leave Egypt on Thursday next by the Florio-Rubattino mail steamer.
El Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of Police, Alexandria, has been granted three months’ leave of absence, from August 5.

A marriage has been arranged between Captain R. N. Knatchbull, D.S.O., the Leicestershire Regiment, son of Colonel Norton Knatchbull, late the Derbyshire Regiment, and Winifred, daughter of William Felton Peel, of Hawley Hill, Blackwater, Hants, and Alexandria, Egypt.

His many friends in Egypt will regret to hear of the death of P. Black Bey, which tools place at 9, Wimbleton, Rothesay, Scotland, on the 24th June last, at the age of 84. Black Bey came to this country in 1863, being one of the first engineers appointed by the late Khedive Ismail Pasha for the erecting of sugar plant in Upper Egypt. He was for many yean chief engineer of Maghagha sugar factory and retired from the Daïra Sanieh on a well-earned pension in 1898. He leaves a widow and a family of five to mourn his loss.
We are glad to hear that Mrs. Plunkett and the young “Oliver” Plunkett are doing well.
Mr. Pierce L. Jarvis, who accompanied Stanley in his search for Livingstone, has died in Brooklyn.

Among the visitors staying at the Bean Rivage, Ramleh, are: Mr. and Mrs. F. H. Boyd Carpenter and family, Mr. and Mrs. T. Moore and family, Cavalier Ugo and Mme Luzzatto and family, Mr. and Mrs. H. div.head: Railway Accident
div.p: Owing to the derailing of two goods trucks the Cairo-Alexandria express was over half an hour late on Saturday.

div.head: Quarantine in Turkey
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Port Said are now subjected to a medical examination and disinfection.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Shoubra district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at daylight on Wednesday will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Carlton Hotel
div.p: We are informed that the management of the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, have still a few excellent rooms to offer to intending visitors to this delightful seaside resort.

div.head: A Fire
div.p: broke out yesterday in the spinning mills at Karmous, and was extinguished by the Fire Brigade. The damage has not yet been ascertained. The origin of the fire was accidental.

div.head: Still they Come!
div.p: Developments in Egypt (says the “Daily Report”) are proceeding apace. Several new companies are being prepared for the market, including more subsidiaries of the Egyptian Mines Exploration.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 8 vessels passed through the Canal on the 29th ulto., 7 of which were British and 1 German. The receipts for the day amounted to frs. 267,794.38, making the total from the 1st June frs. 7,981,933.92

div.head: Fatal Lamp Accident
div.p: A Syrian girl called Rosa Bishara Habib, aged 16 years, expired at the Greek Hospital, Alexandria, yesterday from burns caused by the upsetting of a spirit lamp on which she was boiling milk in her parents’ house in the Attarin quarter.

div.head: Letters to the Editor
div.p: The Editor wishes to point out to correspondents that unsigned letters on any subject cannot be published the “Egyptian Gazette.” Letters must be accompanied by visiting cards, or bear the name and address of the writers, as a guarantee of good faith.

div.head: Stock Exchange Notices
div.p: The committee of the London Stock Exchange has appointed July 5 as a special settling day in Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd.-200,000 shares of £1 each, 5s paid, Nos. 1 to 200,000. The committee has also ordered the above security to be quoted in the official list.

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: During the week ending July 1, 13 deaths from cattle plague were notified throughout Egypt, namely, 2 at Za gazig, 5 at Hehia, and 6 at Shibin-el-Kom. The number of deaths during the corresponding period last year was 1,319. Since the commencement of the epidemic the total number of deaths amounts to 147,291, distributed as follows Gouvernorats, 892 ; Lower Egypt, 54,164 ; Upper Egypt, 92,235.

div.head: Italian Comedy
div.p: The management of the Alhambra Theatre have engaged an Italian comedy company which will occupy the boards of the theatre during August, and which is under the management of Sig. Ernesto Della Guardia. The company is said to be one of the best in Italy, and two of its members are artistes of repute, viz., Sig. Andrea Maggi and Siga. Clara Della Guardia. The company’s repertoire includes Cyrano de Bergerac and the principal works of Gabriele D’Annunzio.

div.head: Death of the Chimpanzee at the Zoo
div.p: We regret to hear that the chimpanzee from the Bahr el Ghazal, which was brought to the Zoological Gardens from Khartoum last autumn, died quite suddenly last Friday night from what is believed to have been kidney disease. Visitors to the gardens will miss the ape, whose imitative powers and gambols always attracted the attention of visitors. Her keeper bad little or no difficulty in taming her and is greatly affected by the death of one of the most interesting animals ever exhibited at Cairo.

div.head: Delivery of Letters
div.p: The continual crease in the demand for house-to-house delivery in Cairo and Alexandria (says a Post Office notice) renders it absolutely necessary that all persons in the towns desirous of such delivery shall have the number of the house and name of the street in which they live indicated on their correspondence. Should by any chance a street be unnamed, then the quarter of the town in which it is situated must be indicated. Attention to these instructions is imperative to avoid delay and errors in the delivery of correspondence.

div.head: “NEDWET EL ASSAL.”
DANGER TO COTTON CROPS.
div.p: The following note has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior :—

"Serious damage to cotton has occurred in past years during the months of August and September, especially in Behera Province, owing to what is known as the ‘Nedwet el Assal.’ In large areas of cotton at Kafr el Dawar and other marakez, which had escaped the worm, and which gave every promise of an excellent crop, the leaves suddenly turned black, the plants became feeble, and a large proportion of the crop was lost. This is attributed to the “Newdet El Assal,” the explanation of which is as follows ;

“At about this period one observes in places that the plants are covered with myriads of tiny green midges (Hemiptera) some with and some without wings. These midges (Aphis) feed upon the leaves by suction, and this, though not sufficient to kill the plants, naturally tends to enfeeble them. At the same time as they feed they deposit on the leaves a sticky kind of honey dew. In the flood season, when the atmosphere is saturated with damp, this honey-dew attracts the spores of a certain sooty fungus which is carried on the wind, and settles wherever this sticky substance is found. The effect is immediate, at once the pores of the leaves are choked, and the plant turns black as stated above. So far, it does not seem possible to deal with the fungus, and the only thing to do is to grapple with the Aphis, as soon as it appears. Accordingly, in any district where the ‘Nedwet el Assal’ is known a careful watch should be kept for the first appearance of the Aphis or midge.

“The following system for killing the Aphis has been tried with great success. The plants are sprayed, with a very fine spraying machine, with a mixture made as follows :—1/2 rotl soap, 1 gallon water, 2 gallons kerosene, and 25 times the bulk of water. The half rotl soap is cut up and boiled in the one gallon of water, until completely dissolved ; it is then taken oft the fire, the two gallons kerosene added, and the whole vigorously stirred. This, when cold, forms a stock solution, which can be kept in bottles ready lor use when required. This emulsion, having been mixed with 25 times the quantity of ordinary water, is put into the sprayer, and pumped on to the plants infected with the Aphis. As the insects usually frequent the lower surface of the leaves, they should be sprayed thoroughly from below, with a final application from above. As it is possible that some insects may escape, the plants should be examined again two or three days after the operation, which should be repeated if any live insects are still found.

"The most important point is to ascertain the districts in which the ‘Nedwet El Assal' has previously appeared. The Aphis has usually been found, so far, on the borders of the cotton fields, near drains and water courses, and the plants should be carefully examined in such places to see if the pest has appeared. If found, spraying should immediately be commenced, and search made in the rest of the field. It is important that the spraying should be done in the early morning of in the evening. The effect of killing the Aphis is that, no honey dew being found, the fungi spores find no material to feed on, and die.

"50 hand pumps (sprayers), specially constructed for throwing a very fine spray in every direction, have been ordered by telegraph from France, and as soon as these are received, they will be issued as required Independently of this, cultivators who have reason to fear the ‘Nedwet el Assal’ will do well to supply themselves with the necessary machines at once, by telegraphing order and money to Messrs. Vermorel, Villefranche(Rhone) France, for “Pulvérisateur, Eclair No. 1”, price (in France), 35 francs. The Daira Draneht Pasha, which suffered severely last year, is already in possession of some 20 of these machines, and special gangs of men are busily engaged upon the destruction of the Aphis, in anticipation of the appearance of the fungus, which may be expected in August. Suitable kerosene, which is preferable to petroleum, can be obtained at about L.E. 2 per ton, from Messrs. Worms & Co., Shell Transport Line, Alexandria. Crude soap refuse, suitable for making the emulsion, could be obtained from the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company’s factory, Kafr el Zayat.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK. LOANS TO OMDEHS.
div.p: The Agricultural Bank has decided that in future all loans granted to omdehs will bear interest at a rate two per cent. lower than that of other loans. This regulation will be made applicable to all existing loans, the instalments of which fall due in or after the month of September, 1905.

It has also been decided to pay to the dallals of the villages a small fee of one piastre tariff for each accepted B. istimara. Dallais presenting themselves at the agencies of the bank will receive payment of all fees due to them up to the end of the previous month. These fees will commence to be allowed on all B. istimaras paid on or after 1st Jane, 1905.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. “Senegal," from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here; to-morrow morning.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: CHOLERA SCARE. NO FOUNDATION FOR REPORTS.
div.p: Rumours have been in circulation during the past day or two that some cases of cholera had occurred at Luxor. H. E. the Regent has, we are informed, received official news to the effect that these rumours are absolutely without any foundation in fact.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, attended by Boutros Pasha Ghali and Col. Watson, left London on Saturday week for Paris. His Highness travelled from Charing-cross in a Royal saloon attached to the 2 20 Folkestone-Boulogne express. The Earl of Cromer was at the station to see him off, and among others present were Sir Rennell Rodd, the British Minister in Stockholm; Sir Ernest Cassel, Sir Vincent Corbett, and General Slade.

div.head: THE REGENCY.
div.p: H. E. Hussein Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works and Public Instruction, will act as Regent and President of the Council and Minister of the Interior in the absence Europe of H. E. Mustapha Fehmy Pasha, who left on Saturday.
H. E. Fakhry Pasha will also act as ad interim Minister of Justice and Foreign Affairs till the return of H. E. Ibrahim Fouad Pasha.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: British officers will wear mourning for the late El Kaimakam Fell Bey up to the 18th July inclusive.
His Highness the Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the promotion of El Kaimakam Mursi Bey Fahmi, commanding 7th Battalion, to be Miralai.
The following Special Army Order has been issued :—
HEAD QUARTERS, KHARTOUM, 25th June, 1905.

The Acting Sirdar announced to the Army with the deepest regret the death of El Miralai W. A. Boulnois Bey, Comman-dant of District and Governor of the Bahr El Ghazal Province, which occurred in the Bahr El Ghazal Province on the 29th May, 1905.
Boulnois Bey joined the Egyptian Army on the 29th November, 1898, and took part in the following campaigns with that Force : -
Nile Expedition, 1899.—Operations resulting in the final defeat of the Khalifa.
Soudan, 1900-2.— Re-occupation of the Bahr El Ghazal Province.
Sudan, 1504-5.— Operations in the Bahr El Ghazar Province.
He was appointed Second in Command of Artillery and Assistant Director of Ordnance, 1st January, 1902, and Commandant of District and Governor of the Bahr El Ghazal Province on the 9th March, 1904.
He was in possession of the 3rd Class Mejidi and the 4th Class Osmani, conferred on him by H.H. the Khedive.

The Acting Sirdar feels that the whole Army shares his sorrow in the loss to it of this valuable Officer, who had rendered exceptionally good services in the Bahr El Ghazal, and had just brought to a satisfactory conclusion, under very trying circumstances, the expedition against the Zande chief Yambio.
By Order,
(Signed) St. GEORGE C. HENRY, Lewa, Adjutant General.

div.head: SUMMER LEAVES.
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to the following officials of the Sudan Government and Army officers -

One month’s extension of leave has been accorded to El Bimbashi Hills, Department of Supplies, and El Bimbashi Channer, 3rd Bat talion, who will return to duty on September 3 and August 1 respectively.
El Bimbashi Travers has received one month’s extension of leave on medical certifi cate, and will resume duty on September 19 accordingly.

div.head: OFFENCES AGAINST MINORS.
div.p: Some ten days ago, on hearing that a house in the Attarin quarter was the scene of offences against girls who were under age, the police, accompanied by the juge d’instruction of the Italian Consulate, made a raid and arrested the keeper of the house, an Italian subject.

Among the inmates were several minors who had been procured for immoral purposes. Some of them were Italian subjects, and the Italian Consulate will in consequence take proceedings against the procuress and keeper of the establishment. The Native Parquet is also undertaking proceedings against the mother of two Armenian girls found there, who are local subjects, for aiding and abetting the commission of certain offences against minors.

div.head: DNEIPER LEAVES PORT SAID. ST. KILDA’S CREW LANDED.
div.p: Sentries were posted all day yesterday alongside the Russian cruiser “Dneiper” and All communication with the shore was forbidden. The Russian Consul had, the previous day, asked the police to prevent boats from approaching the vessel.

I have succeeded in obtaining further details regarding the capture and sinking of the “St. Kilda.” Captain Jones states that after the capture of the vessel the crew were removed to the “Dnieper” and kept close prisoners below decks. Some time before midnight of the 4th June an officer was sent to inform Capt. Jones of the decision of the council of officers, which was, that the “Hilda” was to be destroyed by explosion at dawn next day, Capt. Jones to be present as a witness. The dynamite charges, in spite of over two hours’ work, failed to explode, so the attempt was given up, and shell fire from the forward 4.7 gun was tried from a distance of four cables. The first few shots were ill-placed, but latterly some good shooting was made, 16 shots being fired in all, and the vessel sunk slowly by the bows about 320 miles off Hong-Kong, the two ships having steamed at 9 knots all night in a southerly direction from the scene of the capture.

The captain, officers, engineers, steward, boatswain, and one Chinese boy were allowed go ashore yesterday shortly before the "Dnieper” sailed, which she did at 5.30 p.m., having taken no stores or coal. It was originally intended that the prisoners were to be conveyed to Russia, but another decision was afterwards taken.
The men were allowed to take all their private effects from the “St. Kilda,” and appear to have been well treated and catered for on the “Dneiper,” whose officers speak excellent English.

On the “Dneiper's" arrival the Russian Consul, Mr. Broon, boarded the vessel and conveyed his Government’s instructions to disembark the “St. Kilda’s” men in the afternoon and to retain Capt. Jones, but later fresh orders must have been received, as I myself saw and conversed with him ashore last night at a late hour.

div.head: THE BRITISH WARSHIPS.
div.p: I hear that H.M.S. "Goliath“ and ‘‘Canopus” are to leave on Monday, and that the cruisers “Lancaster” and “Suffolk” are to remain here till further orders, which may mean a stay of over a month more in the port.

An “At Home” was held on board H.M.S. "Lancaster” yesterday afternoon, at which numbers of Port Said residents were present. The ship’s band played all the afternoon and the function was very successful. The band is playing, by special request, at the Eastern Exchange to-night at 9 o’clock.

div.head: A LEVIATHAN MERCHANTMAN.
div.p: The British India S. S. “Queda" arrived from London en route for Karachi yesterday afternoon. She is one of Doxford’s turret ships, is of immense dimensions, and is intended for the British India Company's Indian coast trade. Her registered tonnage is 4,944, and she has a total displacement of 15,529 tons, which allows of her carrying over 12,000 tons of cargo. Her canal dues amount to frs. 495.32 and her displacement makes her the largest vessel which has ever gone through the Canal.

div.head: CRICKET. ALEXANDRIA v. CAIRO.
div.p: This match was played on the A.C.C. ground on Saturday last, but owing to the inability of the Cairo team to get down in the morning, only a half-day’s match could be arranged, play commencing about 2p.m. The Alexandrians opened with H. B. Carver and Strange against the bowling of MacLaren and Miller. Carver soon settled down to his usual hard hitting, though a confident appeal for a catch at the wicket was made when he had scored 25. After the fall of three wickets H. P. Carver joined his brother, who soon reached his century. H. P. Carver was caught at the wicket for 50 and the innings declared closed at 4.30 p.m. for 229, leaving Cairo two hours' play.

Blencoe and Graves started for Cairo, the former playing a forcing innings for 44. Mac-Laren, Trafford, and Bigge played good innings, but, at the commencement of the last over, 8 of the Cairo wickets had fallen for 170 runs. Dawson secured the ninth wicket with the first ball of the over, but failed to defeat the last batsman.
Great thanks must be given to Mrs. S. H. Carver who kindly provided a most excellent tea for all the spectators. Following are the scores :—

div.head: LA REORGANISATION DE L’ENSEIGNEMENT SECONDAIRE
div.p: Le “Journal Officiel” publie dans son dernier numéro la note du Ministère de l’Instruction Publique an conseil des ministres concernant la Réorganisation de l’Enseignement Secon claire. Le texte de cette note que nous donnons ici in extenso a été approuvé par arrêté ministériel en date du 22 écoulé :
Expose des Motifs

Depuis 1897, l’enseignement secondaire comprend trois années d’études seulement. Les jeunes gens qui ont complété l’étude du programme de ces trois années sont admis à subir les épreuves du Certificat d’Études Secondaires.

Le Certificat d’Études Secondaires est exigé pour l’admission aux écoles supérieures du Gouvernement Égyptien, et constitue aussi un titre d’admission aux emplois de l’État rétribués à raison de L.E. 6 par mois, comme traitement de début.

La grande majorité des porteurs du Certificat d’Études Secondaires continuent leurs études dans les écoles supérieures ou entrent au ser-vice des diverses administrations de l’État. C’est ainsi que pour les quatre dernières années, c’est-à-dire depuis 1901, sur 474 jeunes gens qui ont subi avec succès les épreuves du Certificat d’Études Secondaires, 321, soit 68% , ont été admis dans les écoles supérieures égyptiennes ; 25, soit 5 %, ont poursuivi leurs études dans les universités ou écoles supérieures étrangères ; 98, soit 21 %, ont obtenu des emplois dans les administrations de l’État; tandis que 30 seulement, soit un peu plus de 6 %, ont adopté différentes carrières dans des entreprises privées.

Il résulte de ces chiffres que le nombre des porteurs du Certificat d’Études Secondaires qui sont entrés directement au service de l’État après l’achèvement de leurs études secondaires, n’est que de 25 en moyenne par année, nombre qui est loin d’être suffisant pour faire face aux besoins.

Dès l’année 1894, S.E. le Sous-Secrétaire d État au Ministère de l’Instruction publique estimait que l’application du décret du 4 décembre 1892 entraînerait l’obligation pour le Ministère de l'Instruction publique, de fournir annuellement, pour le recrutement du personnel des employés des administrations de l’État, plus de 200 jeunes gens pourvus du Certificat d’Etudes Secondaires, ce qui comportait la nécessité d’entretenir dans les écoles secondaires un contingent d’au moins 2.000 élèves, rien que pour cet objet (Cf. Considérations sur l'Instruction publique en Egypte. Imprimerie Nationale, 1894, page 78, paragraphe 143).

Cette estimation est d’ailleurs entièrement corroborée par les renseignements qui ont été fournis par le Ministère des Finances au Ministère de l’Instruction publique, à la date du 25 avril 1904, no 6, renseignements basés sur les quatre exercices 1900 à 1903 inclusivement, d’après lesquels il est nécessaire de nommer chaque année, en moyenne 250 nouveaux employés pour remplir les vacances qui se produisent dans les emplois inférieurs du cadre.

On comprend dès lors que, vu le petit nombre de jeunes gens pourvus du Certificat d’Études Secondaires qui postulent pour des emplois (25 en moyenne chaque année, quand il en faudrait 250), les administrations soient obligées de nommer aux emplois du cadre des candidats munis seulement du Certificat d’Études Primaires, bien que la plupart des Chefs de service aient exprimé, à maintes reprises, l’opinion que ces derniers n’ont ni la culture générale, ni la maturité d’esprit nécessaires pour remplir d’une façon satisfaisante les fonctions qui leur sont confiées.

Le Ministère de l’Instruction publique s’est depuis longtemps préoccupé de remédier à cette situation défectueuse, en donnant à l’enseignement secondaire le plus grand développement possible. Dès l’année 1897, le Comité Technique avait soumis à l’approbation du Conseil Supérieur, une proposition tendant à enlever au certificat d’Etudes Primaires, le privilège d’être, à partir de l’année 1900, un titre d’admission aux emplois de l’État, dans l’espoir que cette mesure obligerait les candidats aux fonctions civiles à poursuivre leurs études dans les écoles secondaires. Le Conseil Supérieur, dans sa séance du 7 novembre 1897, ne crut pas devoir adopter cette proposition qui lui paraissait prématurée, de sorte qu’aucune amélioration ne put être tentée à cette époque, et ce n’est que lorsque le décret du 24 juin 1901 eut fixé à L.E. 10 le maximum du traitement auquel peuvent atteindre les employés munis seulement du Certificat d’Études Primaires, qu’un progrès sensible a été réalisé. Ainsi le nombre des élèves des trois écoles secondaires existantes, qui était de 569 pendant l’année scolaire 1900-1901, a atteint le chiffre de 1.033 pendant l’année scolaire actuelle, c’est-à-dire a presque doublé ; et selon toute probabilité, il atteindra le chiffre de 1.400 environ pour l’année scolaire prochaine.

Toutefois, s’il est incontestable que ce développement des écoles secondaires permettra d’atténuer, dans une certaine mesure, les graves inconvénients de l’état de choses actuel, il ne faut pas se dissimuler que les progrès qu’il sera possible de réaliser dans cette voie, seront non seulement très lents, mais aussi forcément limités ; et il est peu probable que, par cette amélioration partielle, le Ministère soit jamais en mesure de fournir, à un moment donné, un nombre de jeunes gens munis du Certificat d’Études Secondaires, suffisant pour assurer le recrutement de ses écoles supérieures, et pour remplir les vacances qui se produisent annuellement dans les emplois inférieurs des administrations ; car, tant que le certificat d’Études Primaires donnera accès aux emplois publics, un très grand nombre de jeunes Egyptiens qui l’auront obtenu, préféreront postuler immédiatement pour des emplois, plutôt que de continuer leurs études dans les écoles secon- daires.
(à suivre)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Durant la matinée, le marché a été absolument insignifiant. Les quelques changements introduits à la cote témoignent tous d’une baisse plus ou moins appréciable.

Ainsi la Banque Nationale clôture plus faible à 25 15/16, l’Agricole à 13 1/2, la Land Bank à 9, la Béhéra à 43 1/2, la Daïra à 28, la Khédivial Mail à 4 1/4, l'Alexandria Water à 15, la Delta Light à 12 1/2, la Ramleh Railway à 7 1/8, l’Investment à 1 9/32, et la Salt & Soda à 34/3.
Les transactions ont été nulles et la corbeille a même été désertée pendant longtemps.
La tendance demeure indécise.

div.p: Gum Arabia.—27 bags Persain sold, good pale at 26s, red at 22s 6d, dusty siftings at 20s, pickings part blocky at 10s, dusty siftings at 8s.
Gum Benjamin.—Of 27 cases 2 sold, without reserve, fair Siam 2nd Almond part small and blocky at 12l 5s.
Gum Guaiacum.—3 cases sold at 5d, and 2 cases without reserve, fine glassy block at 8d.
Gum Myrrh.—53 packages bought in, except 13 sold, subject, dark pickings at 59s. to 5ls.
Gum Olibanum. — 6 cases sold without reserve, fair pea size siftings at 26s.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le sculpteur italien, Francesco Petroni, a été appelé de Lucca (en Italie) pour élever un monument à la mémoire de feu Orazio Gustavo Giorgi, secrétaire de la Bourse Khédiviale pendant plus de quarante ans.
L’œuvre a pleinement satisfait la famille du défunt et révèle par le dessin et l’architecture un artiste de grand talent qu’il y aurait avan-tage à voir se fixer à Alexandrie.

div.head: MODERN MERCHANTS OF VENICE.
div.p: The trade and profit of the city Consisteth of all nations.

These words, put by Shakespeare into the month of Antonio, the “Royal Merchant" of Venice, are applicable to the city of the sea unto this day. All nations come to Venice to enjoy her beauty and her splendour, but the Venetians themselves look upon the visitors as their legitimate spoil. Hungrier than Shylock, they are eternally on the poise for prey. Their agents lurk in secret places to pounce on the unsuspecting traveller. They cost him more than Shylock’s pound of flesh in annoyance, anger, and vituperation.

In the days of Antonio and Shylock it was in the district of the Rialto that the Merchants most did congregate. To-day it is the square of St. Mark that they chiefly haunt. They are as ravenous as the pigeons which live in thousands round the Square, and they are almost as numerous.
After breakfast you are sauntering forth from the hotel to do the first duty of the stranger in Venice. That is to say, you are going to St. Mark’s to feed his feathered pensioners.

A man is standing in one of the narrow streets that lead to the Square. He is looking anywhere except at you. As you are about to pass him he wheels round, puts out an insinuating hand, and informs you that he is the proprietor of a lace factory, and that he will be pleased and proud if you will condescend to come and see his hundred girls deftly manufacturing the famous lace. If you go you will be ushered into a small room where half a dozen women are working, and you will be lucky if you escape being made to purchase some lace at twice the price at which it could be bought in London.

A few steps further yon are hooked by another tout. He is the hawk for a firm of glass bead makers. The factory, he explains, is just round the corner. Venice is famous for its glass beads, so you follow him. The exhibition, he explains, is only open that day. By a strange coincidence it also happens to be a free day. Down narrow ways, under alleys and covered courts, past endless turnings he leads you—the factory always being just round the next corner. When at last you arrive you see the process of bead-making, men and women handling heated glass of different colours and fashioning thé glowing masses skilfully into beads. Then when you wish to leave and get to your pigeons in the Square, the proprietor or the manager of the place takes you in hand. He leads you through endless rooms where wares of different kinds are displayed. Very careful is he to impress upon you the fact that he is not showing you these things for the sake of effecting a sale. But he will hint to your wife that a certain set of liqueur glasses are such as could not be bought anywhere in the world except in Venice, and nowhere in Venice at the price at which he is prepared to sell them.

If you do not want them for yourself, he expatiates on their excellence as a wedding present for friends. You find what you think a good excuse in their brittle nature. He is ready for you there. Will he not pack them, post them, and deliver them at your home in England ? All you have to do is to write a cheque, and you will find them waiting for you when you return home after your holiday.

You tell him frankly that you find them too expensive ; he will find that he has made a mistake, and that the price is really so much less. You still hold out, and as a special concession he will take another five, ten, or even fifteen per cent, off. There is only one way of escape, and that is to tell him honestly and firmly that you have no intention of buying anything, and then he will look injured, but accept the inevitable, and lose no time in showing you to the street or to the nearest canal.

So you are in the open again, but other battalions of touts are there waiting for you. Mosaic workers, makers of statuary, glass manufacturers, and a dozen other industries have their harpies eternally on the prowl. Guides infest the approaches to the chief buildings about the Square, and they are mostly ignorant impostors who know nothing about art or history.

While anxious to get anyone who will pay them, they rely for their clients largely on German visitors, who are delighted if they are led from church to church and shown every thing painted or not painted by Titian.

I remember a party of Germans coming into the church of the Frari, the Pantheon of Venice. They were breathless and excited, following a guide who indicated this and that with his finger, and then hurried them on again. The tomb of the unhappy Doge Francesco Foscari is probably the most interesting monument in the church, but the Germans were hurried past this without a reference from the guide, although he led them to a picture not ten yards away, shouting the magic word “Titzian,” while every member of the party snatched a hasty glance and echoed “Ah, Titzian.” Beware, therefore, of the modern Merchant of Venice in the guise of the guide.

Beware also of the gondolier. He has been captured by the Merchants of Venice. The first time you take a gondola the gondolier will suggest a promenade on the grand Canal You, of course, approve. Ten minutes after you have started you will find the gondola rapidly propelled to the side of the canal, where there are the showrooms of some Merchant of Venice or other. “Nothing to pay,” says the gondolier, “everyone visits this gallery.’’ Porters in uniform help you out and you are ushered into showrooms and put through the process again. If you prove an easy victim, the gondolier will drop you into three or four of these ''galleries’' in the course of two hours promenade on the canal. But if you are firm, fierce, and eloquent his gondola will remain in mid-stream, and the Merchants of Venice spread their snares in vain.

The explanation of the nuisance of the touts is simple. They are well paid by the merchants to lure travellers to their shops and show-rooms. Every gondolier who brings bis fare to one of these show-rooms receives either one or two lire (from 10d, to 1s. 8d.), as well as a good commission on whatever purchases are made. Even more is paid to the touts of the streets and the Square. They receive from 2s. 6d. to 5s., and a commission on purchases,

div.head: NO THREAT TO INDIA.
JAPAN CRUSHES RUSSIA’S HOPE OF INVASION.
div.p: A correspondent writing from Odessa says:—

A senior Staff Officer from Tashkend, an old acquaintance of former years in the Crimea, told me on his arrival here that, since passing Tiflis, he had been reading several English journals and a couple of English political magazines, most of which contained articles or paragraphs on the subject of a Russian invasion of India.

“Well,” I asked, “what do you think of such probability ?” “It is all utter nonsense,” my friend replied ; “your people themselves have created this spectre in Russian Central Asia. The Staff at Tashkend have latterly been much amused by reports, or echoes of reports, coming from London to the effect that we were contemplating an ‘aggressive diversion’ against Afghanistan and the sudden seizure of Herat as preliminary to a descent in overwhelming force upon India ! A fantastic chimera of your Russophobes.

“ Where is our overwhelming force to come from ? Where could we now find five Army Corps, the least possible number for such a risky campaign ? You talk of the Transcaspian and Orenburg-Tashkend Railways as two immense military arteries through which our invading legions are shortly to be poured in never-ending streams. One of your so-called expert military commentators, whom I have recently been reading, says that the invasion of India is the only possible means by which Russia can hope to regain her lost prestige. That prestige, I may tell you frankly, is an utterly lost quantity. We cannot rehabilitate it ; we must re-create it, and the re-creation will be a long process.

“On the conclusion of the war Japan will be in possession of Sakhalin. A glance at the map will show you that the warlike possession of that island constitutes a standing menace our great Amur province. The Japanese being alike your defensive and offensive allies, is it not morally certain that the instant our army in Central Asia assumed a threatening attitude towards Afghanistan or India the Japanese would simultaneously threaten the Amur province, and even the whole of Eastern Siberia ?

No, you may take my word for it, that whatever plans were elaborated previously for the invasion of India from Central Asia, the unlooked-for result of the gigantic struggle in the Far East has dissipated them all. The position has been changed, as if by magic, by the sudden and amazing rise of the new Asiatic Titan.”

div.head: COTTON MILL BUILDING.
div.p: At the recent cotton trade congress held in Manchester no mention was made of the reckless cotton spinning mill building that is going on in Lancashire, which, sooner or later, will bring bad margins to masters. The movement will indirectly affect international trade through a largely increased consumption of raw material. Now that the conference is over, many connected with our staple industry feel that the most burning subject was ignored. It is observed that the question ought to have been seriously discussed. Undoubtedly it is no easy thing to stop the flotation of cotton companies. Textile machinists, builders, mill furnishers, and others all join hands in finding themselves work. In a company with £100,000 registered capital, the issue generally ends with £20,000 called up and £80,000 obtained on loan at about 3 1/2 to 4 per cent interest. Hardly a week passes without mill floaters trying their hands at forming a board. The craze is spreading in many small towns and villages. Last week it was Blackrod, near Chorley, because Chorley herself is building a large factory, and so on. The outlook in yarn is poor, owing to prospective over production.

div.head: “HEALTH” AND FICTION.
div.p: What is a “healthy” novel ! The question becomes of interest in view of the scheme afoot in Vienna for extirpating hooliganism by means of innocuous literature, for which "large money prizes” are to be offered. Is the “healthy” novel one in which no murder committed, and all the proprieties are faithfully observed ? It is not till one comes to search for the truly blameless piece of fiction that one realises how rare such a thing really is. How many of Dickens’s stories would pass muster ? Not “David Copperfield” or “Bleak House,” and even "Pickwick” has one or two reprobates. It argues a lack of originality on the part of the lower classes that no bricklayer arraigned for drunkenness has ever pleaded that he was led away by the evil example of Mr. Stiggins, though scores of boys have cited with success the deteriorating influence of Deadwood Dick. The more one contemplates the matter of literature, the more one is led to fear that the novel is in itself a vicious product— that literature if only the voice of a morbid patient telling about his ailments. As the healthy stomach knows nothing of itself, it seems to follow that a healthy society would not bother itself with social problems— could not indeed, for they would not exist. The novels, if any, of that happy era would be as blameless as the multiplication table and as tiresome as the common chord. Just at present, all the really “healthy” novels of the world are given away as prizes in girls’ schools. Perhaps the philanthropists of Vienna will be able to divert some to the new sphere of usefulness, and “sell them on the easiest conditions to the working classes.” But it is just so that Austria is already swarming with Socialists.

div.head: HISTORY OF EGYPT.
div.p: Professor Flinders Petrie has been so assiduous in the work of excavation and travel that the literary part of his activities must necessarily have been “curtailed of its fair proportion.” Yet there is no denying that hard research among the tombs and sand-drifts of a country like Egypt is indispensable to one who makes researches among incunabulae and the crumbling papyri of European museums ; and this is certainly a case where an ounce of recent inquiry at first hand is worth a ton of stale evidence and staler theory accumulated in print It is therefore with gratification that Egyptologists will learn that Messrs. Methuen have published the last volume in six of the Professor’s great “History of Egypt from the Earliest Times to the Present Day.” As they well know, however, the last volume is not the sixth, but the third, and the series has had a gap in it for some years, “like an eye-tooth knocked out,” as Elia puts it. The long-expected volume deals with the crucial period from the nineteenth to the thirtieth dynasties, and the amount of controversial and indefinite matter to be sifted and cleared up more than justifies the delay.

div.head: THE TSAR AND HIS SUBJECTS.
div.p: A few days ago the prospect of constitutional reform in Russia appeared more than hopeful. The Tsar had apparently promised the representatives of the Zemstvos that they would be called to his councils, and that he would govern with their help. Now, all is changed. The newspapers have been told that they quite misunderstood the Imperial words, that they ought not to have done so, and, by way of emphasising the reproof, one of their number, the “Rus,” has been suspended for a month. Several newspapers are accused of having put an arbitrary meaning on His Majesty’s apparently plain utterances. They should have recognised that, whatever he may have said, or seemed to say, it ought to have been understood that he meant his promises to be in accordance with “Russia’s original principles.” “His Majesty’s words contain not the least indication of a possibility of modifying any of the fundamental laws of the Empire.” The Press must, therefore, understand for the future that only the Tsar’s exact language, as reported in the Official Messenger,” is to be given, "without additions or abbreviations.” This, at least, appears to be intelligible, but what does it mean ? Apparently that, for the time being, at any rate, the Imperial mind has come under new influences, and that the bureaucracy has triumphed again. Of course, there may be another change, for the most obvious deduction from what has happened is a new demonstration of the utter instability of the Tsar’s resolutions from day to day. Those who have been fain to hope against hope for reforms must be more than ever inclined to give up their faith. A ruler who cannot be depended upon to remain in the same mind for a single week can never inspire confidence even in the most sanguine of his subjects. (“The Globe”).

div.head: THE APE OF DEATH.
div.p: It is all very well for Mr. Edison to urge that we should sleep for only three hours out of the twenty-four. It may serve for him. He is a phenomenon, who works for eight-and-forty hours at a stretch, then gets up and says, “Isn’t it about time we had some lunch ?” His ability to do without sleep is one of the exceptions which prove the rule. The world has, on the whole, been run, not by men who can go sleepless, but who best could sleep at will. Napoleon and Wellington were alike in this. The Duke could plan a battle upon which the fate of Europe depended, then drop down on to a horse rug and in two minutes be fast asleep. Napoleon had reduced his sleeping to a system. All the projects which excited him he used in fancy to relegate to definite positions in his brain, and as each was disposed of for the moment it would be shut down and forgotten ; and when he wished to sleep he would simply shut down the last lid of his mind—and snore.

It was Cobden’s boast that he could sleep at will. Said he : “If I had not had the faculty of sleeping like a dead fish, in five minutes after the most exciting mental effort, and with the certainty of having oblivion for six consecutive hours, I should not have been alive now.” Gladstone’s sovereign rules were deliberate mastication of his food and “always eight hours' sleep.” So important was this latter consideration that he would never compose anything after six o’clock at night, as to do so would affect his sleep. Some of us would never die if granted as liberal an allowance of assured rest each night. Bright composed his speeches in bed ; that tremendous oration with “the angel of death” and all complete was thought out under his nightcap. Dr. Dollinger, cursed by insomnia, learnt by heart three books of the Odyssey, when seventy years of age, in order to be able to say them over to himself in the silent watches of the night. Thiers was one of the men to whom much sleep —and no less—meant life. He fell fast asleep when discussing with Lord Granville matters of vital interest to France daring the Franco-Prussian war. Granville diplomatically upset the fireirons, and negotiations proceeded.

div.head: ITALY AND THE PAPACY.
div.p: The Pope has just issued an encyclical to the Italian bishops which will probably have a great effect on the politics of the kingdom. It was foreshadowed by the action of some of the clerical party in the recent elections, for it permits strict Roman Catholics to take their share in the political life of the nation. But those who take part in public life must do so under the guidance of the ecclesiastical authorities, which means that the priests are once more to mix in politics. The encyclical, whether it expressly does so or not, as a matter of fact suppresses the “non expedit” by which the clericals were forbidden to exercise their rights as Italian citizens. At the recent general election many of them took part in the voting without a protest from the Vatican. This encyclical, and the announcement that the Pope is about to spend the summer in the country, and so abandon the fiction of the “Prisoner in the Vatican,” shows that the Venetian Pius X. has prevailed over the Cardinals who refused to recognise facts and the new order of things. This change of attitude will lead to an understanding between the Quirinal and the Vatican, and will enable the Pope to accept the five millions of francs which the Kingdom has undertaken to pay him annually. As the French Roman Catholics will no longer be in a position to send money to Rome, this is a consideration not to be lightly rejected.

div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de Canalisation dans la rue Abdel Moneim.

Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 11 juillet 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour la Canalisation rue Abdel Moneim.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 11 juillet à midi.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
